BGP AS_PATH Verification Based on Autonomous System Provider BGP AS_PATH Verification Based on Autonomous System Provider
Authorization (ASPA) Objects Authorization (ASPA) Objects
draft-ietf-sidrops-aspa-verification-13 draft-ietf-sidrops-aspa-verification-14
Abstract Abstract
This document describes procedures that make use of Autonomous System This document describes procedures that make use of Autonomous System
Provider Authorization (ASPA) objects in the Resource Public Key Provider Authorization (ASPA) objects in the Resource Public Key
Infrastructure (RPKI) to verify the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) Infrastructure (RPKI) to verify the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP)
AS_PATH attribute of advertised routes. This type of AS_PATH AS_PATH attribute of advertised routes. This type of AS_PATH
verification provides detection and mitigation of route leaks and verification provides detection and mitigation of route leaks and
improbable AS paths. It also to some degree provides protection improbable AS paths. It also to some degree provides protection
against forged-origin prefix hijacks. against forged-origin prefix hijacks.

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
The Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) as originally designed is known to The Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) as originally designed is known to
be vulnerable to prefix (or route) hijacks and BGP route leaks be vulnerable to prefix (or route) hijacks and BGP route leaks
[RFC7908]. Some existing BGP extensions are able to partially solve [RFC7908]. Some existing BGP extensions are able to partially solve
these problems. For example, Resource Public Key Infrastructure these problems. For example, Resource Public Key Infrastructure
(RPKI) based route origin validation (RPKI-ROV) [RFC6480] [RFC6482] (RPKI) based route origin validation (RPKI-ROV) [RFC6480] [RFC6482]
[RFC6811] [RFC9319] can be used to detect and filter accidental mis- [RFC6811] [RFC9319] can be used to detect and filter accidental mis-
originations. [RFC9234] or originations. [RFC9234] or

using the Confederation's global ASN as the CAS. using the Confederation's global ASN as the CAS.

5. Hop-Check Function 5. Hop-Check Function
An implementation may make its own choice regarding maintaining a
single VAP-SPAS table or two separate tables (i.e., one per AFI).
The former choice may have the advantage of memory savings and higher
cache hit ratio, while the latter may be faster for memory lookups.
Let AS(i) and AS(j) represent adjacent unique ASes in an AS_PATH, and Let AS(i) and AS(j) represent adjacent unique ASes in an AS_PATH, and
thus (AS(i), AS(j)) represents an AS hop. A hop-check function, thus (AS(i), AS(j)) represents an AS hop. A hop-check function,
hop(AS(i), AS(j), AFI), checks if the ordered pair of ASNs, (AS(i), hop(AS(i), AS(j), AFI), checks if the ordered pair of ASNs, (AS(i),
AS(j)), has the property that AS(j) is an attested provider of AS(i) AS(j)), has the property that AS(j) is an attested provider of AS(i)
per VAP-SPAS of AS(i) for the specified AFI. The VAP-SPAS table is per VAP-SPAS of AS(i) for the specified AFI. The VAP-SPAS table is
assumed to be organized in such a way that it can be queried to check assumed to be organized in such a way that it can be queried to check
(1) if for a specified CAS = AS(i), there is an entry (i.e., SPAS (1) if for a specified CAS = AS(i), there is an entry (i.e., SPAS
listed), or (2) if for a given (AS(i), AS(j), AFI) tuple, AS(j) is listed), or (2) if for a given (AS(i), AS(j), AFI) tuple, AS(j) is
listed in the VAP-SPAS as a provider associated with CAS = AS(i) for listed in the VAP-SPAS as a provider associated with CAS = AS(i) for
the specified AFI value. A provider AS ID included in the SPAS can the specified AFI value. A provider AS ID included in the SPAS can
correspond to a Provider, RS, or Sibling. An RS is effectively a correspond to a Provider, non-transparent RS, or Sibling. A non-
Provider to its RS-client. Siblings regard each other as Provider transparent RS is effectively a Provider to its RS-client. Siblings
(see Section 4). The term "Provider+" in the definition of the hop- regard each other as Provider (see Section 4). The term "Provider+"
check function is meant to encompass all three possibilities: in the definition of the hop-check function is meant to encompass all
Provider, RS, or Sibling. This function is specified as follows: three possibilities: Provider, non-transparent RS, or Sibling. This
function is specified as follows:

| "No Attestation" if there is no entry | "No Attestation" if there is no entry
| in VAP-SPAS table for CAS = AS(i) | in VAP-SPAS table for CAS = AS(i)
| |

Figure 1: Hop-check function. Figure 1: Hop-check function.
To be clear, this function checks if AS(j) is included in the VAP-
SPAS of AS(i), and in doing so it does not need to distinguish
between Provider, non-transparent RS, and Sibling.
The hop-check function is AFI dependent because an AS may have The hop-check function is AFI dependent because an AS may have
different SPAS for different AFI. This function is used in the ASPA- different SPAS for different AFI. This function is used in the ASPA-
based AS_PATH verification algorithms described in Section 6.1 and based AS_PATH verification algorithms described in Section 6.1 and
Section 6.2. For simplicity while describing the algorithms, the Section 6.2. For simplicity while describing the algorithms, the
function hop(AS(i), AS(j), AFI) is replaced with hop(AS(i), AS(j)) by function hop(AS(i), AS(j), AFI) is replaced with hop(AS(i), AS(j)) by
dropping the AFI since it is understood that the algorithms are run dropping the AFI since it is understood that the algorithms are run
for a specific AFI at a time (AFI = 1 or AFI = 2). for a specific AFI at a time (AFI = 1 or AFI = 2).
6. AS_PATH Verification 6. AS_PATH Verification

implementation may differ, for example, for computational efficiency implementation may differ, for example, for computational efficiency
purposes but the AS_PATH verification outcomes MUST be identical to purposes but the AS_PATH verification outcomes MUST be identical to
those obtained by the procedures described in Section 6.1 and those obtained by the procedures described in Section 6.1 and
Section 6.2. Section 6.2.
The above applies to eBGP routers in general including those on the The above applies to eBGP routers in general including those on the
boundary of an AS Confederation facing external ASes. However, the boundary of an AS Confederation facing external ASes. However, the
procedures for ASPA-based AS_PATH verification in this document are procedures for ASPA-based AS_PATH verification in this document are
NOT RECOMMENDED for use on eBGP links internal to the Confederation. NOT RECOMMENDED for use on eBGP links internal to the Confederation.
The procedures specified in this document may be used in scenarios
that use private AS numbers behind an Internet-facing ASN (e.g., a
data-center network [RFC7938] or stub customer), but any details are
outside the scope of this document.
The procedures described in this document MUST be applied to BGP The procedures described in this document MUST be applied to BGP
routes with {AFI, SAFI} combinations {AFI 1 (IPv4), SAFI 1} and {AFI routes with {AFI, SAFI} combinations {AFI 1 (IPv4), SAFI 1} and {AFI
2 (IPv6), SAFI 1} [IANA-AF]. The procedures MUST NOT be applied to 2 (IPv6), SAFI 1} [IANA-AF]. The procedures MUST NOT be applied to
other address families by default. other address families by default.
8. Mitigation 8. Mitigation
If the AS_PATH is determined to be Invalid based on the verification If the AS_PATH is determined to be Invalid based on the verification
procedures specified above (Section 6), then the route SHOULD be procedures specified above (Section 6), then the route SHOULD be
rejected. rejected. Also, for any route with an Invalid AS_PATH, the cause of
the invalidity SHOULD be logged for monitoring and diagnostic
purposes.
The ASPA-based path verification procedures are able to check routes The ASPA-based path verification procedures are able to check routes
received from customers, lateral peers, transit providers, RSes, RS- received from customers, lateral peers, transit providers, RSes, RS-
clients, and siblings. These procedures combined with BGP Roles clients, and siblings. These procedures combined with BGP Roles
[RFC9234] and RPKI-ROV [RFC6811] [RFC9319] can provide a fully [RFC9234] and RPKI-ROV [RFC6811] [RFC9319] can provide a fully
automated solution to detect and filter many of the ordinary prefix automated solution to detect and filter many of the ordinary prefix
hijacks, forged-origin prefix hijacks, and route leaks. hijacks, forged-origin prefix hijacks, and route leaks.
The ASPA-based path verification has the following properties The ASPA-based path verification has the following properties
(detection capabilities): (detection capabilities):
1. Let AS A and AS B be any two ASes in the Internet doing ASPA Property 1: Let AS A and AS B be any two ASes in the Internet
(generation and verification) and no assumption is made about the doing ASPA (generation and verification) and no assumption is made

from AS A to a customer or lateral peer and leaked by an propagated from AS A to a customer or lateral peer. The route is

at AS B always detects such a route leak though it may not be ASPA-based path verification at AS B always detects such a route

an RS-client. (or AS B received from) is an RS-client.

3. Consider an ASPA island (i.e., a connected set of ASPA capable Property 3: This is an extension of Property 2 above to the case
ASes). Let AS A and AS B be any two ASes in the ASPA island. of prefix hijacking with a forged-path-segment. Such hijacking
Consider a route propagated from AS A in any direction (i.e., to refers to the forging of multiple contiguous ASes in an AS path
a neighbor AS with any of the BGP roles described in Section 2) beginning with the origin AS. Again, let AS A and AS B be any two
and leaked by an offending AS in the AS path before being ASes in the Internet doing ASPA (generation and verification).
received at AS B from any direction. The ASPA-based path Let AS A's providers, AS P and AS Q, also be doing ASPA. No
verification at AS B always detects such a route leak though it assumption is made about the ASPA deployment status of any other
may not be able to identify the AS that originated the leak. ASes in the Internet. Consider a route received at AS B on a
customer or lateral peer interface that is a prefix hijack with a
forged-path-segment {AS P, AS A} or {AS Q, AS A}. That is, the
hijacker attaches this path-segment at the beginning of their
route announcement. The ASPA-based path verification at AS B
always detects such a forged-path-segment prefix hijack. For a
chance to be successful (remain undetected), the hijacker may
resort to a forged-path-segment with three ASes including a
provider AS of AS P (or AS Q). But even that can be foiled
(detected) if the providers of AS P and AS Q also do ASPA. Just
having to use a longer forged-path-segment by itself also
diminishes the ability of the hijacked route to compete with the
corresponding legitimate route in path selection (assuming both
have "Unknown" verification status).
Property 4: Consider an ASPA island (i.e., a connected set of ASPA
capable ASes). Let AS A and AS B be any two ASes in the ASPA
island. Consider a route propagated from AS A in any direction
(i.e., to a neighbor AS with any of the BGP roles described in
Section 2). The route is subsequently leaked by an offending AS
in the AS path before being received at AS B from any direction.
The ASPA-based path verification at AS B always detects such a
route leak though it may not be able to identify the AS that
originated the leak.
An observation that follows from Property #1 above is that if any two An observation that follows from Property #1 above is that if any two
ISP ASes register ASPAs and implement the detection and mitigation ISP ASes register ASPAs and implement the detection and mitigation
procedures, then any route received from one of them and leaked to procedures, then any route received from one of them and leaked to
the other by a common customer AS (ASPA compliant or not) will be the other by a common customer AS (ASPA compliant or not) will be
automatically detected and mitigated. In effect, if most major ISPs automatically detected and mitigated. In effect, if most major ISPs
are compliant, the propagation of route leaks in the Internet will be are compliant, the propagation of route leaks in the Internet will be
severely limited. severely limited.
The above properties show that the ASPA-based path verification The above properties show that the ASPA-based path verification
